Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Unraveling the post-Pliocene Arctic Ocean transition to the icehouse climate
Award.AbstractNarration: Funds are provided to allow the PIs to develop a continuous record of changes in the Arctic Ocean in response to climatic cooling and growth of ice sheets in the Early to Middle Pleistocene based on sediment cores from the western Arctic Ocean. They will utilize a suite of proxies (microfaunal assemblages, stable and radiogenic isotopes, biomarkers, sediment mineralogy and elemental composition and grain size) to reconstruct variations in glacial inputs, sea ice, and water circulation. The use of paleobiological and geochemical proxies will be greatly enhanced by a unique sediment core that has a rich calcareous microfossil record extending through most of the Quaternary and potentially into the Pliocene, unlike other cores from the Arctic Ocean. This is a unique find that they can capitalize on as Arctic cores typically preserve calcareous microfossils only in Late Quaternary sediments. Age control will be achieved by paleomagnetic, 10Be, Sr-isotope, and cyclostratigraphic methods. This research will allow them to test whether there was an overall progressive growth in ice sheets and sea-ice cover and if sea ice and continental glaciers changed synchronously. They will also test whether the Mid Pleistocene Transition led to the growth of a super-thick Laurentide Ice Sheet by analyzing changes in glacial inputs from the northern Laurentide margin, with a multi-century scale record for the threshold glaciation ca. 650 ka, which initiated the icehouse world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The alarming retreat of sea ice and melting of the Greenland ice sheet gives urgency to assessing the Arctic’s response to climate change. Due to the limited scope of Arctic instrumental records, paleoclimatic reconstructions of past climates are critical for understanding the full range and pace of natural climate variability and the sensitivity of the Arctic to these changes. The available evidence for past changes in the Arctic Ocean is scarce especially for times older than the last ~0.2-0.3 Ma (million years) due to difficulties of obtaining long sediment cores and mostly poor preservation of many sedimentary proxies (such as biological remains, chemical compounds etc) used for reconstructing past environments.

The goal of this proposal was to develop a record of changes in the Arctic Ocean in response to climatic cooling and growth of ice sheets during the last 1-2 Ma based on sediment cores from the western Arctic Ocean. This area, characterized by an especially thick and expansive sea-ice cover in historic times, is now the arena of the most dramatic sea-ice retreat (Figure 1). Investigating changes of sea-ice and related oceanographic conditions in the past, especially during the intervals of changing climate, is important for evaluating the ongoing change. A suite of proxies for the past oceanic environments (microfossil assemblages, stable and radiogenic isotopes, sediment composition and grain size) was utilized to reconstruct variations in impacts on sedimentation and seafloor life from ice sheets, sea ice, and water circulation. The efficiency of paleobiological and geochemical proxies was greatly enhanced by a use of sediment core with a rich calcareous microfossil record extending to estimated ~1.5 million years, much longer than in other cores investigated from the Arctic Ocean.

Warmer hydrographic conditions with predominantly seasonal sea ice in the early part of the investigated record (until ~0.8 Ma) are indicated by proxies investigated in this research (Figure 2). This oceanic regime may have been related to a stronger inflow of Pacific waters into the Arctic Ocean due to an overall higher sea level in a warmer world with only limited ice sheets existing in the Northern Hemisphere. This climatic setting can be potentially used as a past analog for the projected near-future state of the Arctic. Results obtained for the later part of the record suggest that perennial (year-round) sea ice in the western Arctic was getting more persistent and became a norm for most of the last ~0.5 Ma, in contrast to rapidly disappearing summer ice today. This past sea-ice development was accompanied by a rapid expansion of circum-Arctic ice sheets, notably the Laurentide ice sheet, in an overall cooling climate. In addition to assessing paleo ice conditions, an important outcome of this study is the message that life in the Arctic Ocean is strongly affected by changes in ice cover, which implies that Arctic biota will likely suffer from the ongoing sea-ice melting, consistent with results of recent biological observations and models.
